title: early-mid 4th century B.C.): likely Aeneas of Stymphalus, a general of the Arcadian League in the Peloponnese. A writer of several military studies relevant to the 4th century B.C. his only surviving work deals with sieges
390-314 B.C.): Athenian orator, statesman and soldier whose surviving speeches shed light on 4th century events

note: century B.C.): Historian who served with Alexander and wrote of his reign, a major influence on Arrian.
title: 380-320 B.C.): Historian from Lampsacus who composed works now lost on the history of Greece

title: 384-322 B.C.): Greek philosopher and tutor of Alexander the Great whose works provide details relevant to warfare in 4th century B.C. Greece

container-title: A. Selincourt trans]; The Landmark Arrian, The Campaigns ofAlexander
title: late 1st-early 2nd century A.D.): Lucius Flavius Arrianus, Greekborn Roman soldier and historian and author of an account of the career of Alexander the Great. (Arrian, The Campaigns ofAlexander
late 2nd-late 1st century B.C.): Philosopher and writer of an academic work on military affairs relevant to the 4th century B.C
327 B.C.): Greek historian whose works are now lost, but provided some information on 4th century B.C. events to surviving histories, including that of Diodorus

publisher: Quintus Curtius Rufus, The History ofAlexander
title: early 1st century A.D.): Quintus Curtius Rufus, Roman soldier and historian and author of a history of Alexander the Great in Latin
384-322 B.C.): Greek orator, statesman and soldier whose speeches yield details on 4th century B.C. events

container-title: B.C.): Sicilian historian whose surviving works include coverage of events in the 4th century B.C. Greek world
title: 1st century B.C.): Prolific compiler of ancient writings whose works contributed important details on 4th century B.C. history via scholiasts

container-title: events in the surviving works of others, including Diodorus and Plutarch. Frontinus
note: c. A.D. 35-103): Roman writer whose collection of military stratagems includes many from 4th century B.C. Greek warfare.
title: late 1st century B.C.): Greek historian whose surviving works detail early Roman history and shed light on events in Grecian Italy
Ephorus of Cyme
B.C.): Greek historian whose work is now lost, but was used as a source on 4th century B.C

480s-420s B.C.): Greek historian often referred to as the `father of history' whose work culminates at the end of the Persian invasion of 480-79 and offers insights on military affairs relevant to the 4th century B.C
389-322 B.C.): Athenian statesman and orator whose surviving speeches contribute details on 4th century B.C. events
436-338 B.C.): Greek orator whose speeches provide detail on 4th century B.C. events

container-title: 59 B.C.- A.D. 17): Roman historian whose works include useful detail on the warfare among the Italians relevant to the 4th century B.C. (Livy, Rome and Italy, Books VI-X of The History of Rome from its Foundation
title: Iunianius lustinus, a Roman writer who summarized the now lost work of Pompeius Trogus, which came largely from Greek sources and included coverage of 4th century B.C. (Justin, Epitome of the Philippic History ofPompeius Trogus
Livy
458-380 B.C.): Athenian speech writer whose surviving works shed light on events in the early 4th century B.C
110-24 B.C.): Roman writer whose works included biographies of a number of 4th century B.C. Greek generals
1st century A.D.): Greek philosopher who wrote a treatise on generalship that includes information relevant to 4th century B.C. warfare
late 5th-early 4th century B.C.): Greek writer known from fragments found in Oxyrhynchus (in Egypt) whose work includes coverage of the early 4th century B.C

container-title: B.C.): Greek historian whose works survive only in fragments, specialized in the history of Attica and was a major source for other Hellenistic chronographers. Plato
B.C.): Greek philosopher and student of Socrates whose works contain information regarding 5th and 4th century B.C. military matters
title: 2nd century A.D.): Greek travel writer whose works include numerous historical details relevant to the 4th century B.C
Philistus
B.C.): Sicilian historian whose work is now lost, but provided source material to Timaeus and, hence, to Diodorus on events in Sicily during the 4th century B.C
45-120): Greek philosopher and writer whose works include biographies of Greek military figures of the 4th century B.C
2nd century A.D.): Macedonian rhetorician whose collection of stratagems include many from the 4th century B.C. Greeks
B.C.): Greek historian whose works on the 3rd and 2nd centuries B.C. also shed some light on 4th century B.C. military practices
367/66-282 B.C.): Macedonian general and Hellenistic ruler of Egypt (as Ptolemy I) whose lost history of Alexander heavily influenced other historians
64 B.C.-post A.D. 21): Most important geographer of ancient times, whose works supply numerous details about places and events in the 4th century B.C
1st century B.C.): Roman historian whose work relevant to the 4th century B.C. drew from earlier Greek sources and is lost save for summarization in Justin

note: c. 350-260 B.C.): Greek historian whose work, now lost, sourced the surviving works of others, including Diodorus and Plutarch.
title: 400 B.C.): Greek historian and Athenian general whose work on the Peloponnesian Wars of the 5th century B.C. has relevance for 4th century B.C. military affairs as well
Timaeus
430-350 B.C.): Greek general and historian whose works include coverage of Greek wars down to 362 B.C
